HEALTH AND SAFETY AT WORK

Do you remember the scenario?

 

 

By  not telling his employees about the ergonomics risk, Mike has breached his obligation to:

Scenario

 

Mike is the owner of MSP Advisory Services, a tax consulting business.

 

After reading an article on the internet, Mike becomes concerned about the duties which he may owe to his employees in regards to work health and safety. He is worried that he may not be able to carry out one of his obligations and so decides to transfer this obligation to one of the managers.

 

Part of MSP's office is about to be renovated. Mike has received an ergonomics report that the new workstations to be installed as part of the renovation pose a severe ergonomics risk. The report recommends the immediate redesign of the workstations.

 

Mike decides not to share this information with his employees. The renovations will happen in a section of the office where his employees don't spend too much time working, and he is worried that redesigning the workstations will put a financial strain on the business.

Allow employees to decide whether the renovation should go ahead

Consult with his workers

Disclose all health and safety information to workers

 
 
 

That is incorrect

 

In order to meet the obligation to consult with workers about a health and safety matter that directly affects the workers, a PCBU must share relevant information about the matter with workers.

That is correct!

 

In order to meet the obligation to consult with workers about a health and safety matter that directly affects the workers, a PCBU must share relevant information about the matter with workers.

That is incorrect

 

In order to meet the obligation to consult with workers about a health and safety matter that directly affects the workers, a PCBU must share relevant information about the matter with workers.
